citing_paper_authors: Timothy, Baldwin | Colin, Bannard | Takaaki, Tanaka | Dominic, Widdows
raw_text: Indeed, Schone and Jurafsky (2001) provide evidence that suggests that WordNet is as effective an evaluation resource as the web for MWE detection methods, despite its inherent size limitations and static nature. Two MWE types that are particularly well represented in WordNet are compound nouns (47,000 en tries) and multi word verbs (2,600 entries)
clean_text: Indeed, Schone and Jurafsky (2001) provide evidence that suggests that WordNet is as effective an evaluation resource as the web for MWE detection methods, despite its inherent size limitations and static nature.

raw_text: Schone and Jurafsky (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001) applied Latent-Semantic Analysis (LSA) to the analysis of MWEs in the task of MWE discovery, by way 900 of rescoring MWEs extracted from the corpus
clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001) applied Latent-Semantic Analysis (LSA) to the analysis of MWEs in the task of MWE discovery, by way of rescoring MWEs extracted from the corpus.

citing_paper_authors: Lukas, Michelbacher | Alok, Kothari | Martin, Forst | Christina, Lioma | Hinrich, Schütze
raw_text: To our knowledge, there are no generally accepted answers to these questions. Regarding (i), Schone and Jurafsky (2001) compare the semantic vector of a phrase p and the vectors of its component words in two ways: one includes the contexts of p in the construction of the semantic vectors of the parts and one does not
clean_text: Regarding (i), Schone and Jurafsky (2001) compare the semantic vector of a phrase p and the vectors of its component words in two ways: one includes the contexts of p in the construction of the semantic vectors of the parts and one does not.

citing_paper_authors: Lukas, Michelbacher | Alok, Kothari | Martin, Forst | Christina, Lioma | Hinrich, Schütze
raw_text: Statistical association measures are frequently used for MWU detection and collocation extraction (e.g. Schone and Jurafsky (2001), Evert and Krenn (2001), Pecina (2010))
clean_text: Statistical association measures are frequently used for MWU detection and collocation extraction (e.g. Schone and Jurafsky (2001), Evert and Krenn (2001), Pecina (2010)).

citing_paper_authors: Lukas, Michelbacher | Alok, Kothari | Martin, Forst | Christina, Lioma | Hinrich, Schütze
raw_text: We use all measures used by Schone and Jurafsky (2001) that can be derived from a phrase? s contingency table
clean_text: We use all measures used by Schone and Jurafsky (2001) that can be derived from a phrase's contingency table.

citing_paper_authors: Lukas, Michelbacher | Alok, Kothari | Martin, Forst | Christina, Lioma | Hinrich, Schütze
raw_text: As our baseline, we use two methods of comparing semantic vectors :sj1 and sj2, both introduced by Schone and Jurafsky (2001)
clean_text: As our baseline, we use two methods of comparing semantic vectors: sj1 and sj2, both introduced by Schone and Jurafsky (2001).

raw_text: Examples include automatic thesaurus extraction (Grefenstette, 1994), word sense discrimination (Schu ?tze, 1998) and disambiguation (McCarthy et al, 2004), collocation extraction (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001), text segmentation (Choi et al, 2001), and notably information retrieval (Salton et al, 1975)
clean_text: Examples include automatic thesaurus extraction (Grefenstette, 1994), word sense discrimination (Schutze, 1998) and disambiguation (McCarthy et al, 2004), collocation extraction (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001), text segmentation (Choi et al, 2001), and notably information retrieval (Salton et al, 1975).

raw_text: By contrast, Schone and Jurafsky (2001) evaluate the identification of phrasal terms without grammatical filtering on a 6.7 million word extract from the TREC databases, applying both WordNet and on line dictionaries as gold standards
clean_text: By contrast, Schone and Jurafsky (2001) evaluate the identification of phrasal terms without grammatical filtering on a 6.7 million word extract from the TREC databases, applying both WordNet and on line dictionaries as gold standards.

raw_text: Since Schone and Jurafsky (2001) demonstrated similar results whether WordNet or on line dictionaries were used as a gold standard, WordNet was selected
clean_text: Since Schone and Jurafsky (2001) demonstrated similar results whether WordNet or on line dictionaries were used as a gold standard, WordNet was selected.

raw_text: There have also been a number of papers focusing on the detection of semantic non-compositional items in recent years beginning with the work of Schone and Jurafsky (2001)
clean_text: There have also been a number of papers focusing on the detection of semantic non-compositional items in recent years beginning with the work of Schone and Jurafsky (2001).

citing_paper_authors: Michael, Stipicevic | Robert, Lindsey | William P., Headden III
raw_text: Furthermore, lists of topical unigrams are often made only marginally interpretable by virtue of their non-compositionality, the principle that a collocation? s meaning typically is not derivable from its constituent words (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001)
clean_text: Furthermore, lists of topical unigrams are often made only marginally interpretable by virtue of their non-compositionality, the principle that a collocation's meaning typically is not derivable from its constituent words (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001).
